front.title: By default reject route propagation when no policy is associated with the BGP session.

abstract.t: This document defines the default behavior of a BGP speaker when no import or export policy is associated with a BGP session.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Introduction
section.t:
BGP speakers have many default settings which need to be revisited as part of improving the routing ecosystem. There is a need to provide guidance to BGP implementers for the default behaviors of a well functioning Internet ecosystem. Routing leaks
are part of the problem, but software defects and operator misconfigurations are just a few of the attacks on Internet stability we aim to address.

Many BGP speakers accept all routes from a neighbor by default. This practice dates back to the early days of the Internet, where operators were permissive in offering routing information to allow all networks to reach each other. As the Internet has become more densely interconnected, the risk of a misbehaving BGP speaker poses significant risks to Internet routing.

This specification intends to improve this situation by requiring the explicit configuration of a BGP import and export policy for any EBGP speaking session such as customers, peers, or confederation boundaries in a base router or VPN instances. When this solution is implemented, devices will no longer accept or send routes without policies configured on EBGP sessions.

section.title: Solution Requirements
section.t:
The following requirements apply to the solution described in this document:
Software MUST mark any routes from an EBGP peer as 'invalid' in the Adj-RIB-In, if no import policy was configured. Software MUST NOT advertise any routes to an EBGP peer, if no export policy was configured. Software MUST provide protection from internal failures preventing the advertisement and acceptance of routes. Software MAY provide a configuration option to disable this security capability. Software MUST operate in this mode by default.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document addresses the basic security posture of a BGP speaking device within a network. Operators have a need for implementers to address the problem through a behavior change to mitigate against possible attacks from a permissive security posture. Attacks and inadvertent advertisements cause business impact necessitating this default behavior.
